questions.text: A 4-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents because he falls frequently, cannot jump, and tires easily. On examination, he has proximal muscle weakness affecting the pelvic and shoulder girdles and hypertrophy of the calf muscles. Serum creatine kinase is markedly elevated. Histologic examination of calf muscle shows variation in fibre size, necrosis, regeneration, and endomysial fibrosis. Immunohistochemical staining shows the absence of the normal sarcolemmal dystrophin staining pattern. A molecular assay would most likely show abnormalities in the transcript of which of the following proteins?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD) is caused by mutations in the dystrophin gene located on the X chromosome (Xp21). This gene encodes a key structural protein that connects the actin cytoskeleton of the muscle fibre to the extracellular matrix via the dystrophin-glycoprotein complex.

  • The absence or severe reduction of dystrophin in DMD leads to increased fragility of the sarcolemma and abnormal calcium influx.
  • This results in cycles of muscle fibre necrosis, regeneration, and eventual fibrosis.
  • Histology shows muscle fibre size variation, necrosis, myophagocytosis, regenerating fibres, and endomysial fibrosis.
  • Immunohistochemistry shows the absence of sarcolemmal dystrophin in DMD and reduced staining in Becker muscular dystrophy.
  • Creatine kinase is elevated due to muscle membrane damage, but it is not a structural transcript affected by mutation.
  • Desmin is a cytoskeletal protein, but it is not typically altered in DMD.
  • Glycogen phosphorylase is involved in glycogenolytic disorders (e.g., McArdle disease), not DMD.

Explanation of Other Options:

Creatine kinase (Option A): Enzyme released due to muscle fibre damage; elevated in DMD but not due to transcriptional mutation.

Desmin (Option B): Intermediate filament protein; not involved in the dystrophin-glycoprotein complex or DMD pathogenesis.

Glycogen phosphorylase (Option D): Deficient in McArdle disease, a metabolic myopathy unrelated to dystrophin mutations.

questions.text: A 10-year-old girl complains of persistent redness of the skin over her knuckles and around the nail beds. She describes easy fatigability and can rise only with difficulty from a squatting position. Physical examination reveals erythema over the knuckles and a heliotrope rash. A muscle biopsy shows infiltrates of B and T lymphocytes around blood vessels and in connective tissue of the perimysium. Elevated serum levels of which of the following would be expected in this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Creatine kinase is elevated in dermatomyositis due to immune-mediated muscle injury, which leads to muscle fibre necrosis and regeneration.

  • Dermatomyositis is an autoimmune inflammatory myopathy characterised by proximal muscle weakness and characteristic skin findings such as:
    • Heliotrope rash
    • Gottron papules
  • Histopathology shows:
    • Perifascicular atrophy of muscle fibres
    • Mononuclear inflammatory cell infiltrates (CD4+ T cells, B cells)
    • Infiltration around small blood vessels and perimysium
  • Muscle enzyme levels, such as creatine kinase and aldolase, are elevated due to active muscle fibre damage.
  • Skin involvement often precedes or accompanies muscle weakness.

Explanation of Other Options:

Alkaline phosphatase (Option A): Enzyme of liver and bone; not elevated in muscle inflammation.

Alpha-fetoprotein (Option B): Tumour marker; not related to inflammatory myopathies.

Carcinoembryonic antigen (Option C): Tumour marker used in colorectal cancer follow-up.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man has had increasing progressive muscle weakness in both arms and legs along with dysarthria and difficulty in swallowing for the past 2 years. He is now wheelchair-bound. Physical examination shows 3/5 motor strength in all extremities. He has no muscle pain on palpation, no deformities or loss of joint mobility, and no tremor. A biopsy specimen of the quadriceps muscle is obtained, and microscopic examination shows no inflammation, but only atrophy of the myofibers. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a progressive neurodegenerative disorder affecting both upper and lower motor neurons. The hallmark is denervation-type muscle atrophy without associated inflammation.

  • ALS typically presents with asymmetric weakness, dysarthria, dysphagia, and progressive muscle wasting.
  • Both upper motor neuron signs (spasticity, hyperreflexia) and lower motor neuron signs (muscle wasting, fasciculations) are seen.
  • Muscle biopsy shows atrophic fibres due to denervation; inflammation is absent.
  • ALS does not involve sensory, cognitive, or autonomic functions early, distinguishing it from other myopathies.

Explanation of Other Options:

Becker muscular dystrophy (Option B): X-linked disorder with milder course and later onset than Duchenne; muscle biopsy shows dystrophin deficiency, not pure denervation atrophy.

Mitochondrial myopathy (Option C): Shows ragged red fibres and mitochondrial abnormalities; often includes CNS signs or lactic acidosis.

Myasthenia gravis (Option D): Autoimmune disorder affecting neuromuscular junction with fatigable weakness; no atrophic myofibers seen on biopsy.

choices.text: Absolute eosinophil count in peripheral blood
PCR to detect expansion of CGG repeats on chromosome Xq27.3
Presence of oligoclonal bands of immunoglobulin in cerebrospinal fluid

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy develops increasing muscle weakness. He is unable to play with other children because he quickly tires and is unable to keep up with them. On physical examination, he is afebrile. No deformities are noted. He has 4/5 muscle strength in his extremities, with more apparent weakness of the proximal muscles. Laboratory studies show a serum creatine kinase level of 689 U/L. A muscle biopsy is performed, and the microscopic appearance is shown below. Which of the following tests would be most appropriate to confirm the diagnosis in this boy?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Immunohistochemical staining for dystrophin is used to confirm the diagnosis of Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD), which is characterised by progressive proximal muscle weakness in early childhood and marked elevation of serum creatine kinase.

  • Muscle biopsy findings in DMD typically show variation in fibre size, internalised nuclei, fibre necrosis, endomysial fibrosis, and replacement of muscle by adipose tissue.
  • Dystrophin protein is absent in DMD and reduced in Becker muscular dystrophy. IHC or Western blot helps confirm the absence of dystrophin in affected muscle fibres.
  • Dystrophin gene mutation is located on the X chromosome and encodes a protein that connects the cytoskeleton of muscle fibres to the extracellular matrix.
  • The histological image shows fibrofatty replacement and muscle fibre degeneration, consistent with DMD.

Explanation of Other Options:

Absolute eosinophil count (Option A): Not relevant; used in eosinophilic myopathies or parasitic infections.

PCR for CGG repeats on Xq27.3 (Option C): Related to Fragile X syndrome, a cause of intellectual disability, not muscular dystrophy.

Oligoclonal bands in CSF (Option D): Seen in multiple sclerosis and other CNS inflammatory conditions, not myopathy.

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman injured her leg in a motor vehicle accident and subsequently suffers from weakness in her left lower leg. A biopsy of the gastrocnemius muscle obtained after 4 months is shown below. Which of the following best characterises this pathology?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Denervation atrophy is characterised histologically by angular atrophic muscle fibres, often grouped together due to loss of lower motor neuron input.

  • After injury to motor nerves, muscle fibres lose innervation and become atrophic.
  • These atrophic fibres appear angular on biopsy and are often clustered, forming fibre-type grouping.
  • The image clearly shows small, angular atrophic fibres surrounded by larger normal fibres, consistent with neurogenic atrophy due to denervation.
  • This matches the classic pattern seen after trauma, causing lower motor neuron injury.

Explanation of Other Options:

Autoimmune myopathy (Option A): Shows lymphocytic infiltrate and necrotic fibres, typically with perifascicular atrophy (seen in dermatomyositis), not angular fibre atrophy.

Compensatory hypertrophy (Option B): Would show enlarged fibres, not small, angular, atrophic ones.

Mitochondrial depletion (Option D): Characterised by ragged red fibres or COX-negative fibres, not angular fibre atrophy.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man recovering from a 'flu' complained of marked fatigue. He reports that he cannot climb stairs two at a time as he used to. He also describes pain in his thighs. A muscle biopsy (shown in the image) demonstrates a mononuclear inflammatory cell infiltrate chiefly in the endomysium. Immunostaining shows that most of these inflammatory cells are CD8+ T lymphocytes. What is the appropriate diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The image shows an endomysial mononuclear inflammatory infiltrate predominantly composed of CD8+ cytotoxic T cells, which is characteristic of polymyositis

  • Polymyositis is related to direct muscle cell damage produced by cytotoxic T cells.
  • Healthy muscle fibres are initially surrounded by CD8+ T lymphocytes and macrophages (see photomicrograph), after which muscle fibres degenerate.
  • There is a frequent association between polymyositis and anti-Jo-1, an antibody against histidyl-tRNA synthetase, with the concomitant presence of interstitial lung disease, Raynaud phenomenon, and nonerosive arthritis.
  • Although viral infections (e.g., influenza) may trigger polymyositis, muscle tissue has not yielded a virus on culture.
  • An inflammatory myopathy indistinguishable from polymyositis occurs in many cases of HIV infection, but the role of the lentivirus is unclear.

Explanation of Other Options:

Dermatomyositis (Option A): Characterised by CD4+ cell infiltrates in perimysial or perivascular areas; often seen with skin rash and perifascicular atrophy, not seen here.

Myasthenia gravis (Option B): A neuromuscular junction disorder with no muscle inflammation or CD8+ infiltrates on biopsy.

Myotonic dystrophy (Option C): A genetic disorder; shows internalised nuclei and muscle fibre atrophy but not inflammatory infiltrates.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man who had been treated for lung cancer complained of a rash on his chest and pain in his upper arms and calves. He cannot raise his arms and climbs the stairs only with difficulty. A muscle biopsy shows perivascular infiltrates of lymphocytes and plasma cells extending between the muscle fibres along with perifascicular atrophy (as shown below). Immunofluorescence reveals immune complexes in the walls of intramuscular blood vessels. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The correct diagnosis is Dermatomyositis, an immune-mediated inflammatory myopathy characterised by microangiopathy with complement-mediated capillary damage, leading to ischemic muscle fibre injury, most prominently in the perifascicular region.

Explanation of Other Options:

Becker muscular dystrophy (Option A): A genetic dystrophinopathy showing muscle fibre degeneration and regeneration without perivascular inflammation or perifascicular atrophy.

Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome (Option C): A paraneoplastic disorder involving presynaptic calcium channels; typically spares muscles on biopsy and lacks rash or inflammatory infiltrate.

Myasthenia gravis (Option D): Autoimmune disease affecting postsynaptic acetylcholine receptors; no histological muscle inflammation or skin involvement.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents with muscle weakness. He cannot open his hand for a handshake and cannot extend his arm after flexing it. On physical examination, he has marked atrophy of leg and arm muscles, ptosis, and a fixed facial expression. There is testicular atrophy. Laboratory studies demonstrate mild diabetes. A muscle biopsy reveals atrophy of type I fibres, hypertrophy of type II fibres, and numerous fibres with centrally located nuclei. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Myotonic dystrophy is the diagnosis due to the clinical picture of systemic involvement with delayed muscle relaxation and characteristic biopsy features.

  • Myotonic dystrophy, the most common form of adult muscular dystrophy, is an autosomal dominant disorder characterised by slow muscle relaxation (myotonia) and progressive muscle weakness and wasting.
  • In addition to skeletal muscle, myotonic dystrophy affects many systems, including the heart, smooth muscle, central nervous system, endocrine glands, and eyes.
  • Myotonic dystrophy can be separated into two clinical groups: adult-onset and congenital. Most adult patients display atrophy of type I fibres and hypertrophy of type II fibres.
  • Unlike the other choices, internally situated nuclei are a constant feature. Necrosis and regeneration, although occasionally present, are not as prominent as they are in Duchenne muscular dystrophy.

Explanation of Other Options:

Dermatomyositis (Option A): Shows perifascicular atrophy and inflammatory infiltrates, typically not seen in this case.

Duchenne muscular dystrophy (Option B): More common in children; biopsy shows necrosis, regeneration, and pseudohypertrophy, not prominent central nuclei.

Limb-girdle muscular dystrophy (Option C): Involves proximal muscles but lacks systemic features or characteristic central nuclei.

questions.text: Electron microscopy of muscles was performed in an infant who presented with hypotonia at birth. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The presence of hypotonia at birth suggests a congenital myopathy. On electron microscopy, the key diagnostic finding is the presence of subsarcolemmal aggregates of rod-shaped (nemaline) structures, which are pathognomonic for Nemaline myopathy.

Explanation of Other Options:

Duchenne muscular dystrophy (Option A): X-linked disorder with onset in early childhood, not congenital; EM does not show nemaline rods.

Myotonic dystrophy (Option B): Typically adult-onset with type I fibre atrophy and internal nuclei; not associated with nemaline bodies.

Fascioscapulohumeral muscular dystrophy (Option C): Presents later in life with facial and shoulder weakness; not congenital and no rod bodies on EM.

questions.text: X-ray of the foot shows a lytic lesion in the calcaneus. Biopsy from the lesion shows the histological image below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The histology shows sheets of mononuclear cells, hemosiderin-laden macrophages (brownish pigment), and scattered multinucleated giant cells, which are diagnostic of Pigmented Villonodular Synovitis (PVNS), now called Tenosynovial Giant Cell Tumour (TGCT). This is a benign but locally aggressive neoplasm that arises from the synovium of joints, tendon sheaths, and bursae.

  • Colour and texture: Reddish-brown colour due to hemosiderin explains the historical name "pigmented" villonodular synovitis.
  • Bone involvement: Pressure erosions can be seen in adjacent bone, such as the calcaneus.
  • Site: Commonly involves large joints like the knee, but can also involve ankle and foot (e.g., calcaneus).
  • Histology: Foamy histiocytes, hemosiderin pigment, mononuclear stromal cells, and osteoclast-like giant cells.

Explanation of Other Options:

Onchonosis (Option B): Refers to onchocerciasis, a parasitic infection caused by Onchocerca volvulus, affecting the skin and eyes, not associated with lytic bone lesions or synovial proliferation.

Osteomyelitis (Option C): A bacterial infection of bone presenting with inflammatory infiltrates, necrosis, and reactive bone formation, lacks giant cells and hemosiderin-laden macrophages seen here.

Eumycosis (Option D): Fungal infection (e.g. eumycetoma) typically shows granules with fungal hyphae, neutrophilic response, and abscess, not the mononuclear and giant cell pattern seen in this synovial tumour.

questions.text: Forward scatter in flow cytometry indicates?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Forward scatter (FSC) in flow cytometry provides information about the cell size, as it measures the light scattered in the forward direction when a laser beam hits the cell.

  • FSC is proportional to the surface area or volume of the cell.
  • The image (attached) shows a schematic of flow cytometry with the forward scatter detector positioned along the path of the laser light.
  • Side scatter (SSC), on the other hand, is detected at a 90° angle and reflects internal granularity or complexity.

Explanation of Other Options:

Nucleus (Option B): Not specifically assessed by forward scatter; nuclear features are better visualised with DNA-binding dyes or cytometry markers.

Granularity (Option C): Measured by side scatter, not forward scatter.

DNA content (Option D): Measured using fluorescent dyes like propidium iodide, not by forward scatter.

questions.text: Identify the HPLC pattern:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

HPLC shows elevated HbA2 (>4%) with normal to high HbA (>90%) and slight elevation in HbF (<1%), which is the hallmark of β-thalassemia trait.

  • Key diagnostic clues in HPLC:
    • HbA2 = 4.9% (↑) → hallmark of β-thalassemia trait
    • HbF = 0.8% (↑ or N)
    • HbA >90%
  • Classical β-thalassemia trait features:
    • Caused by a heterozygous mutation in the β-globin gene (β+ or β°)
    • Elevated HbA2 >4% on HPLC is diagnostic
    • Mild anaemia, microcytosis (MCV <75 fL), low MCH (<27 pg)

Explanation of Other Options:

β-thalassemia major (Option B): HPLC shows absent HbA, very high HbF (>90%), and normal/low HbA2.

HbS disease (Option C): Characterised by a prominent HbS peak, low/absent HbA, and variable HbF, not isolated HbA2 elevation.

Iron deficiency anaemia (Option D): Associated with low HbA2 levels (<2.5%), often confused with β-thalassemia trait but distinguished by HbA2 values and clinical context.

Reference: Malays J Med Sci. 2001: https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC3413648/

questions.text: The given technique is very important in the diagnostic field. Which of the following is an important component for viewing by this technique?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The given technique is immunofluorescence, and the dichroic mirror/tube is a critical optical component used in this setup.

  • Immunofluorescence (IF) is a powerful approach for getting insight into cellular structures and processes using microscopy.
  • Specific proteins can be assessed for their expression and location.
  • An immunofluorescence experiment is based on the following principal steps:
    • Specific antibodies bind to the protein of interest.
    • Fluorescent dyes are coupled to these immune complexes in order to visualise the protein of interest using microscopy.

Dichroic Mirror

With epi-illumination, the dichroic mirror serves as the primary optical element separating the excitation and emission light. The common mode of operation is that the shorter excitation wavelength is reflected toward the specimen, and the longer emitted wavelength is transmitted by the dichroic mirror.

Explanation of Other Options:

Cathode Ray tube (Option A): Used in older television and monitor displays, not in immunofluorescence microscopy.

Dark field/phase condenser (Option C): Used in dark field and phase contrast microscopy, not in immunofluorescence.

Phase plate (Option D): Component of phase contrast microscopy, unrelated to fluorescence optics.

Reference: Wulf B. Storch, Immunofluorescence in Clinical Immunology

questions.text: NaF is used in which colour cap vacutainer?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Grey cap vacutainers contain sodium fluoride (NaF), which acts as an antiglycolytic agent.

  • Purpose: Prevents glycolysis in the blood sample, preserving glucose for accurate estimation.
  • Additional component: Often combined with potassium oxalate, which acts as an anticoagulant by binding calcium.

Explanation of Other Options:

Yellow (Option B): Contains SPS; used in blood cultures to prevent bacterial destruction.

Red (Option C): No additive; used when serum is needed.

Blue (Option D): Contains sodium citrate for coagulation studies.

Reference: StatPearls, Laboratory Tube Collection: Techniques, https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK555991/

choices.text: To get a differential leukocyte count

questions.text: Flow cytometry is used to detect?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Flow cytometry is a laboratory technique used to rapidly and quantitatively assess several cell characteristics. It is especially important in identifying and classifying hematopoietic malignancies like leukaemias and lymphomas.

  • Flow cytometry detects cell surface antigens, allowing identification of T-cell and B-cell subtypes.
  • It requires viable cells in suspension and is based on the binding of fluorescent-labelled antibodies to cell surface markers.
  • It is not used for antibody quantification (done by ELISA), differential counts (done by automated haematology analysers), or coagulation profile (done by coagulometers).

Explanation of Other Options:

Antibody quantification (Option A): Performed by ELISA; not the primary use of flow cytometry.

To get differential leukocyte count (Option B): Done by automated blood cell counters, not flow cytometry.

To give a coagulation profile (Option D): Coagulation profile is assessed using a coagulometer, not by flow cytometry.
